Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance is meeting a new person who seems shy and nervous in a social setting.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: I stood in the corner of the bustling living room, holding my cup of tea, when I noticed a new face—someone who looked as out of place as I sometimes felt. As an acquaintance, I knew I should approach her, offer a smile, and help her feel welcome. That’s what people expected of me: to be warm, open, and attentive. But as I took a step forward, I felt the familiar tug of my other self—the part of me that clung to my Hindu roots. I hadn’t had time for my full morning ritual, so I’d been quietly repeating a short mantra under my breath throughout the day, hoping it would be enough. Now, as I prepared to greet her, I felt the words of the mantra on my lips, the need to finish it before I spoke. I hesitated, torn between the urge to fulfill my social role and the quiet, persistent call of my faith. My heart pounded as I stood there, caught between the expectations of being a good acquaintance and honoring my spiritual practice, unsure which part of myself to answer first.
